comment_data.body:
The `\s*` at the end is useless. At least without a `$`. Not sure if I want to add that. Let's relax it for now.
```suggestion
        no_cover = re.compile(r'#\s*pragma:\s*no\s+cover').search
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -218,6 +218,7 @@ def _parse_cfile_lines(self, c_file):
             r'(?:struct|union|enum|class)'
             r'(\s+[^:]+|)\s*:'
         ).match
+        no_cover = re.compile(r'#\s*pragma:\s*no\s+cover\s*').search

comment_data.body: done
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -218,6 +218,7 @@ def _parse_cfile_lines(self, c_file):
             r'(?:struct|union|enum|class)'
             r'(\s+[^:]+|)\s*:'
         ).match
+        no_cover = re.compile(r'#\s*pragma:\s*no\s+cover\s*').search

comment_data.body:
Except that, in this case, it's because `func3()` really is not executed anywhere. ;)

I'd add a second line to it, without pragma, and make sure that gets executed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -154,6 +158,7 @@ def run_report():
 
     assert  7 not in files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx'][-1], files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx']
     assert 12 not in files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx'][-1], files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx']
+    assert 15 not in files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx'][-1], files['coverage_test_pyx.pyx']

comment_data.body:
The pragma works in the beginning or the end of a function (also on multiple lines) but not in the middle. I must be missing something.

I mean that in
```python
def fun1():
    a = 5  # pragma: no cover
    b = 5
    return a + b

def fun2():
    a = 5
    b = 5
    return a + b  # pragma: no cover

def fun3():
    a = 5
    b = 5  # pragma: no cover
    return a + b
```
`fun1` and `fun2` produce the result I expect but `fun3` ignores the pragma.


I am working on it.

comment_data.body: Is this option tested anywhere?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+class NoCoverConfigurer(CoveragePlugin):
+    exclude_lines = []
+
+    def configure(self, config):
+        type(self).exclude_lines = config.get_option("report:exclude_lines")

comment_data.body: Well, yes: It may not be obvious but the plugin does not have any defaults anymore for `report:exclude_lines` so that the fact that the test using `# pragma: no cover` work actually rely on that class.

comment_data.body: Ok, got it, I think. The `FileReporter` now implements `excluded_lines()`, and the `NoCoverConfigurer` picks it up from there. That's not immediately obvious, but yes, it's tested. :)

comment_data.body:
Is it correct to use `type(self)â€¦` here? This feels too global for a module specific result. Doesn't this work as well?
```suggestion
        # Pass on the "excluded_lines" as found by the "CythonModuleReporter" below.
        self.exclude_lines = config.get_option("report:exclude_lines")
```

comment_data.body: I am not fond of global variables either. However, I could not find a method on `Plugin` that would receive `Configurer` instances so that I do not think that an instance attribute would work.

comment_data.body: No, I do not think it is. The calls in `coverage_init()` register the classes with the `coverage` library but I am not sure that users are supposed to keep track of the instances. The globals are ugly but coverage runs once and exits.

comment_data.body:
> coverage runs once and exits

If you run it from the CLI, then yes. There's an API interface to it, too, though, and I'd like to keep that working. I'd say that prohibits global state.

comment_data.body:
Yes, I understand but the configuration is fairly static: Either a file on the filesystem or the global defaults. I do not think that the configuration can be changed in an instance. Global constants are OK.

There may be a more elegant way to achieve this, however. I could not find any fitting example and the documentation only describes the API.

comment_data.body:
The "lines" are indeed regexes. I am not sure why they call it that but the naming is that of `coverage` so that we should just use it. It is most likely possible to implement the `configure()` method on `Plugin` and to register it both as a `configurer` and a `file_tracer`. However, I would rather keep the responsibilities separated.

In the end, I am only interested in the functionality. So feel free to modify this code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,13 +50,23 @@ def _find_dep_file_path(main_file, file_path, relative_path_search=False):
     return canonical_filename(abs_path)
 
 
+class NoCoverConfigurer(CoveragePlugin):
+    exclude_lines = []
+
+    def configure(self, config):

comment_data.body:
> I am not sure why they call it that

The name reads well when used in a config file, referring to "exclude lines â€¦ that look like these". It makes less sense when used in code that processes the entries, where it suggests a reference to specific lines or line numbers. I needed to look up the documentation of coverage plugins in order to understand this implementation. That suggests that something was lacking from the code, be it in terms of comments or naming.

> I would rather keep the responsibilities separated.

If it's at the price of globally storing duplicate configuration that coverage stores internally, I'd rather not.

In the end, it's mostly a style issue. I'll revert my last change and merge this, then see what else I can do.

commit.message:
Do not cover lines marked `# pragma: no cover`

Issue #3680.
Try if using a better contained instance attribute works as well.

author scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de> 1599302321 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1599302321 +0200

Try if using a better contained instance attribute works as well.

commit.message: Add and fix comments to make it clearer what is going on. Might be better done by improving the naming, though.

commit.message: Avoid a separate plugin (and a global variable) just to read the excluded lines from the coverage configuration.

verification.payload:
tree bc4795acb4fbc24530fc4f941488613041e09356
parent 1880dead48ca0825ef925f054173f9825c1e070d
author scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de> 1599493398 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1599493398 +0200

Avoid a separate plugin (and a global variable) just to read the excluded lines from the coverage configuration.

commit.message: Fix the case that no line exclusions are configured.
